title-group.article-title: In vitro study of poly(ethylene terephthalate) implants for long-term durability

author-notes.corresp: Mashiur Rahman, The University of Manitoba, 35 Chancellors' Circle, Winnipeg MB R3T 2G6, Canada. Email: rahmanm@cc.umanitoba.ca

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In vitro investigation was carried out using two loading conditions (applied and pre-loading) and three aqueous chemicals to study the in vivo formation of longitudinal and circumferential cracks in poly(ethylene terephthalate) or PET implants. Scanning electron microscopy determined that in vivo formation of longitudinal cracks can be detected by treating the PET with aqueous NaOH in relaxed and loading conditions; both longitudinal and circumferential cracks can be detected by treating the PET with aqueous NaOH under applied and pre-loading conditions above the yield load. The detected longitudinal and circumferential cracks were similar to those found in PET implants in vivo. Treatments using acid and ammonium hydroxide did not produce any longitudinal or circumferential cracks either in relaxed (zero load) or applied loading conditions. The calculated lifetime was approximately 50 years under zero applied loading conditions and pH of 10–11. The major contributing factor for the premature rupture of medical-grade PET implants resulting in numerous human deaths was physiological load.

body.p: Poly(ethylene terephthalate), or PET, is widely used for many medical applications, including implants. However, numerous reports show human deaths resulting from PET graft failures,1–3 and the actual number of deaths from PET graft failures could be much higher than those documented, since fear of litigation could prevent reporting of failures.1,4–6 Other factors could also contribute to the underestimation of graft failures. Among these are surgical failures of grafts, such as thrombosis and infection, rather than the failure of the textile material, or death of elderly patients from natural causes or causes other than graft failure.5 In vivo, both circumferential and longitudinal cracks were observed on the ruptured polyester7–10 and polypropylene implants.11 Repetitive pulsatile blood flow pressure, high blood pressure and body fluid environments are responsible for premature rupture of PET implants.5 These physiological stresses on implant materials can be continuous or intermittent; for example, an Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) graft encounters constant stress.12 On the other hand, all vein grafts are subjected to arterial pulse pressure.13 The average time for implant failures is usually 7.0 years, but it ranges from 12 months to 19 years.5 White and Hann14 reported that residual stress in textile implants generated during textile processing (spinning, winding, warping, sizing and weaving) was responsible for the formation of cracks and the deterioration in mechanical properties through chemical degradation. Low-temperature cast coagulation technique has been used in an attempt to minimize the residual stress during production and formation of cracking during use; however, these implants still have produced stress-cracks in vivo due to hydrolytic degradation.15

Alkalis and amines have long been used to understand the fine structures of apparel-grade PET.16,17 Early PET implants used apparel-grade polymers and processing equipment; however, developments in spinning and polymer technology (spin finish, process machineries) have made it possible to produce high-tenacity PET for medical applications where long-term durability is required.18,19 PET yarns for industrial applications (medical applications, geosynthetic applications) require complex drawing and heat treatment in order to obtain the required tenacity, extensibility, thermal shrinkage, orientation and crystallinity of fibers.20 For example, the tenacity and extensibility of apparel-grade polyester is 26 cN/tex and 30–40%, respectively, whereas the value is 85 cN/tex and 7% for industrial-grade fiber.21 In the USA and Canada, it is mandatory to record implant failure with the Federal Drug Administration (FDA)22 and Health Canada,23 respectively, outlining ‘event description’ and ‘manufacturer narrative’, as well as deterioration of effectiveness of the medical device that has led to death or serious deterioration in the state of a patient. It is not legally required to submit laboratory test results for performance evaluation simulating accelerated physiological conditions. In our previous study, we demonstrated that alkaline degradation of PET under applied loading conditions produced surface cracks when the applied load was above the yield load at room temperature.24 In the present study, the investigation used two loading conditions (applied load and pre-load) and three aqueous chemical solutions (sodium hydroxide, sulfuric acid and ammonium hydroxide) to determine if the in vivo formation of circumferential and longitudinal cracks in PET implants can be predicted before implantation. Furthermore, in this study, we have used empirical equations to calculate the approximate lifetime of the PET implants made from high-tenacity medical-grade polymer.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Two high-tenacity bright PET samples were used for the present study. The sample is coded as follows: PET-A (Trevira 730, 1100 dtex/200f, 74 N/tex) and PET-B (Tergel Tech, 1100 dtex/192f, 80 cN/tex). The chemicals used were analytical grade (AR). Solutions of sodium hydroxide, sulfuric acid and ammonium hydroxide were made up in distilled water and stored in plastic bottles. The concentration (w/v) of NaOH was 10%, the concentration (w/v) of H2SO4 was 5% and the concentrations of NH4OH were 2% and 5%.

sec.title: Relaxed samples (zero stress)
sec.p: The samples in relaxed conditions (without any stress or pre-stress) were treated in chemical solutions without any stressing condition.

sec.title: Stressing the samples and creating applied load during chemical treatment
sec.p: A stainless steel tube (16 cm long, 1 cm diameter) was used to keep the samples under stress during chemical treatments. The tube contained numerous small holes (approximate diameter: 1.0 mm) and two larger holes (approximate diameter: 2.0 mm). A yarn sample 2 meters in length was tied at one end of the tube through a larger hole, while the other end of the yarn was attached to various loads (1000 g or 123 MPa; 2000 g load or 246 MPa). The yarn, whilst under this applied load, was then carefully wound onto the stainless steel tube, and secured by wrapping several turns around a screw that was then tightened in the larger hole at the other end of the tube to maintain the applied stress. Such stressed samples were then immersed in an 85 ml solution of chemicals (alkali, acid and ammonium hydroxide) in polypropylene dyeing tubes and shaken periodically at a required temperature in a water bath.

sec.title: Pre-stressed (pre-loaded) sample
sec.p: The preparation of the pre-stressed (pre-loaded) sample is described as follows. To create residual stress, the yarn was wound as for the stressed sample using various loads (246 MPa or 2000 g, 123 MPa or 1000 g); however, the stressed sample was kept in a stressing condition for 24 hours. The yarn sample was then unwound from the tube and treated in a relaxed condition, that is, without any stress on the sample, with chemical solutions.

sec.title: Hydrolysis procedures
sec.p: The relaxed, stressed (applied-loaded) and pre-stressed (pre-loaded) samples were then treated with 85 ml of alkali, acid or ammonium hydroxide solution in polypropylene dyeing tubes in a Rotadyer for different treatment conditions. After alkaline treatments, samples were soaked in water for 5 minutes and then immersed in 100 ml of 0.1% HCl for 10 minutes. Final washing in water was continued until the pH was neutral. After acid treatment, samples were soaked in water for 5 minutes and then immersed in 100 ml of 0.1% NaOH for 10 minutes. Final washing in water was continued until the pH was neutral. Treated yarns were allowed to dry at room temperature to constant weight, then weight losses were measured. Except for the NH4OH samples, all samples were treated at 40℃. NH4OH samples were treated at room temperature (20–23℃).

sec.title: Weight loss measurement
sec.p: The weight loss (%) was calculated by taking the weight of the untreated and treated samples using the following formula: Weightloss( %)= (W1-W2 )W1×100 W1=weightoftheuntreatedsample;W2=weightofthetreatedsample. where W1 is the weight of the untreated sample and W2 is the weight of the treated sample.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: The mechanical properties of individual filaments taken from treated yarns were determined on an Instron 1026 universal tester with the series IX test method. The crosshead speed was 50 mm/min, the 500 g load cell was used and the full-scale load was 100 g. Fiber samples were first glued onto cardboard squares with an inner dimension of 20 mm and the framed fibers were clamped in the tester at a 20 mm gauge length. Prior to testing, all fibers were conditioned according to ASTM D 1776: Practice for Conditioning and Testing Textiles, at 20℃ and 65% relative humidity for at least 48 hours. Twenty (20) specimens of each sample were tested, and the average values and standard deviations of breaking load were measured. The yield load of the fiber was determined with the ‘Slope-Threshold’ method, as described in the Instron Manual.25

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p: The treated samples were coated with gold and examined on a Cambridge Sterioscan S360 connected to a Quantimet 570 Image Analyzer.

sec.title: Changes in properties of NaOH-treated PET
sec.p:
The weight loss (%), breaking load (cN) and breaking load (%), along with surface characteristics of PET-A and PET-B samples treated in aqueous NaOH in relaxed (zero load), applied loading and pre-loading conditions, are given in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. The weight loss (%) for both PET samples treated in aqueous NaOH in a relaxed condition (no applied or pre-load) increased with increasing treatment time. A similar trend in weight loss (%) increase with treatment time was observed for the samples treated with aqueous NaOH in applied loading (Table 1) and pre-loading (Table 2) conditions. However, the weight loss (%) of the applied-loaded and pre-loaded samples was higher than the relaxed samples for similar treatment conditions. For example, after 96 hours of treatment in aqueous NaOH, the relaxed PET-A samples (PET-A/NaOH/zero load) lost 15.3% weight, whereas the applied-loaded samples (PET-A/NaOH/246 MPa applied load) lost 20.2%, and the pre-loaded samples (PET-A/NaOH/246 MPa pre-load) lost 19.4% weight. Table 1.

Table 2.
Weight loss (%), breaking load loss (%) and surface characteristics of the NaOH-treated pre-loaded samples
Treatment conditions Time (h) Weight loss (%) Breaking load (cN) Breaking load (%) Scanning electron micrograph Comments on cracks formation
PET-A/NaOH/246 MPa pre-load 48 7.9 33.8 ± 2.3 29.3 Not shown Both circumferential and longitudinal cracks

One reason for the slight increases in weight loss (%) for the stressed and pre-stressed samples was the increase in surface area, or reduction in linear density of the fiber due to stress, as the relationship was found to be inverse between weight loss (%) in alkaline medium and fiber decitex (weightloss( %)∝1/d): d is the fiber decitex).26

The breaking load loss (%) for the relaxed samples treated in aqueous NaOH was similar to the corresponding weight loss (%), except for the 96 hour-treated samples. The 96 hour-treated samples in the relaxed condition (PET-A/NaOH/zero load) produced a higher breaking load (%) than the corresponding weight loss (%). The breaking load loss (%) for the applied-loaded (PET-A/NaOH/246 MPa applied load, PET-B/NaOH/246 MPa applied load) and pre-loaded samples (PET-A/NaOH/246 MPa pre-load; PET-B/NaOH/246 MPa pre-load) were much higher than the corresponding weight loss (%). The reason for the higher breaking load (%) for the applied-loaded and pre-loaded samples than the relaxed samples will be discussed in the Scanning electron micrograph section.

sec.title: Changes in properties of H2SO4 and NH4OH-treated poly(ethylene terephthalate)
sec.p:
The weight loss (%), breaking load (cN) and breaking load loss (%) for PET-A samples treated with H2SO4 and NH4OH are given in Tables 3 and 4, respectively. The weight loss (%) was negligible for sulfuric acid-treated samples in relaxed and applied loading conditions. However, the breaking load loss (%) was significantly higher for all three conditions, and increased with the increasing treatment time. For example, the sample (PET-A/H2SO4/246 MPa applied load) treated with 5% H2SO4 for 96 hours lost 70% of the breaking load. A similar trend in weight loss (%) and mechanical loss (%) was observed with the NH4OH treated samples (Table 4). The degree of attack on the mechanical properties of PET by the aqueous solution of NH4OH is dependent on the solution concentration and stressing conditions. While the weight loss (%) of NH4OH-treated samples was unchanged, the breaking load loss (%) increased with the increasing applied loading conditions and concentration of NH4OH. For example, at 2% NH4OH and 246 MPa applied load, the breaking load loss was 23.5% compared to 69.1% for 5% NH4OH under similar treatment conditions (Table 4). The weight loss (%) data agree with the data published in the literature, as no weight loss (%) was obtained when PET was treated in aqueous ammonia at 30℃ for 10 days27 and n-butylamine at 21℃ for 72 hours.17 However, a small amount of weight loss (3.3%) was reported when polyester was treated with 10% (w/w) aqueous solution of ethanolamine for 6 hours at 100℃.17 Table 3.
Weight loss (%), breaking load loss (%) and surface characteristics of the H2SO4-treated samples in applied loading condition

PET-A/H2SO4/246 MPa applied load 48 **NS 30.8 ± 1.8 35.6 Figure 7 Smooth
PET-A/H2SO4/246 MPa applied load 72 **NS 21.8 ± 2.2 54.3 Not shown Smooth

sec.title: Scanning electron micrographs
sec.p:
The scanning electron micrographs in Figures 1 and 2 were obtained for the virgin (untreated) PET-A and PET-B samples. No cracks or grooves can be seen in these two PET samples. Figure 3 shows the surface appearance of the PET-A sample treated in the relaxed condition (PET-A/NaOH/zero load) for 96 hours with 10% NaOH (weight loss: 15.3%). The overall fiber surface treated with alkali in the relaxed condition is rougher than the surface of the virgin PET sample. Although no circumferential cracks were seen on this micrograph (Figure 3), a few longitudinal pits can be observed. These longitudinal pits are similar to those obtained in the alkaline hydrolyzed PET samples containing titanium dioxide28 and are responsible for the larger breaking load loss (%) than the corresponding weight loss (%). In contrast, the micrograph of PET-B (PET-B/NaOH/zero load) treated in the relaxed condition for up to 96 hours in 10% NaOH (weight loss: 18.5%) did not produce any longitudinal or circumferential cracks. No noticeable longitudinal pits were observed when samples of PET-A (PET-A/NaOH/zero load) were treated for up to 72 hours (weight loss: 11.9%) in the relaxed condition with 10% NaOH. Figure 1.
Scanning electron micrograph of virgin PET-A.
Figure 2.
Scanning electron micrograph of virgin PET-B.
Figure 3.
Scanning electron micrograph of PET-A treated in the relaxed state with 10% NaOH, 96 hours.

The surface characteristics of PET are different for different loading conditions and PET types. When the applied load was below yield load (<246 MPa) of PET, only longitudinal cracks were observed in the PET-A samples (scanning electron micrographs not shown) and no visible cracks in either direction were observed in the PET-B samples (scanning electron micrographs not shown), except the 96 hour-treated samples with 123 MPa applied loading condition, which shows the onset of crack formation. However, when the applied load was above the yield load of 2000 g or 246 MPa, severe circumferential and longitudinal cracks were generated in the PET-A samples (Figure 4), and longitudinal cracks were seen in the PET-B sample (Figure 5). The length and width of the cracks increased with the severity of the hydrolysis. The yield load was determined by the ‘Slope-Threshold’ method using an Instron Universal Strength Tester and was found to be 1220 g for PET-A and 1240 g for PET-B. The longitudinal cracks were more prominent in the stressed PET-A sample (Figure 4: PET-A/NaOH/246 MPa applied load) than the relaxed PET-A sample (Figure 3: PET-A/NaOH/zero load) for similar hydrolysis conditions. The longitudinal crack patterns (crack length, width and frequency) are different for PET-A (Figure 4) and PET-B (Figure 5) for similar treatment conditions. The difference in dimensions of crack size in PET-A and PET-B is due to the presence of different size crystals, which depend on the processing history. The size and number of crystal formation is dependent on the nucleation rate, that is, heat-setting and cooling rate. It is known that smaller and more numerous crystals are formed with a high nucleation rate, while larger and fewer crystals are formed with a slow nucleation rate.21 Figure 4.
Scanning electron micrograph of PET-A treated with 10% NaOH, 96 hours/2000 g load.
Figure 5.
Scanning electron micrograph of PET-B treated with 10% NaOH, 96 hours/2000 g load.

The circumferential and longitudinal cracks in the stressed PET samples are similar to those observed in the ruptured PET implants in vivo that resulted in numerous human deaths.7,9,10 No crack was observed when samples were treated under loading conditions in water alone (micrograph not shown). While the circumferential cracks were generated due to the applied load, which was above the yield load and alkaline environment, the longitudinal cracks in the PET-A sample might have originated from surface defects or been due to the presence of TiO2, as the sample is bright and contains about 0.1% TiO2, although TiO2 should not be used in medical-grade PET as it damages cell membranes.29 Alternatively, the PET-A sample might have manufacturing defects, possibly from the heat-setting treatments.

Since it is evident that surface defects can be detected by treating PET with NaOH in relaxed and applied loading conditions, further investigations were carried out to determine if other loading conditions and chemicals could be used to detect such defects in PET implants before their implantation into the human body. One such loading condition was ‘pre-loading’ the PET samples before their treatment with the alkaline solution. This pre-loading condition creates residual stress in the samples. The residual stress in the textile structure is generated in two ways: (a) during transformation from fibers to yarns and yarns to fabrics (spinning/winding/warping/weaving) and (b) during normal functioning in the human body due to intermittent pulsatile forces. It is reported that the residual stress in the textile structure is responsible for premature rupture of small-caliber straight tubes (bifurcated grafts, femoro-popliteal grafts and axillo-femoral grafts).5 Figure 6 shows the scanning electron micrographs obtained from the pre-stressed sample of PET-A (PET-A/NaOH/246 MPa pre-load) treated in 10% alkaline solution at 40℃. Both circumferential and longitudinal cracks can be seen in this micrograph. In contrast, only circumferential cracks are present in the PET-B pre-stressed (PET-B/NaOH/246 MPa pre-load) sample (micrograph not shown here). The longitudinal cracks in the pre-stressed sample (Figure 6) are much wider and deeper than the relaxed sample (Figure 3); however, both longitudinal and circumferential cracks are much less prominent than those in the 246 MPa applied-loaded samples (Figure 4). The longitudinal cracks in the pre-stressed sample are much more prominent than the circumferential cracks. It seems that the longitudinal cracks in all three alkaline-treated PET-A samples (relaxed: Figure 3, applied loaded: Figure 4 and pre-loaded: Figure 6) are parallel to each other and the angle between the longitudinal cracks and fiber axis is approximately 2–5° (Figure 6). Similar longitudinal pits and craters have been observed in the explanted Vanguard stent grafts.7 Figure 6.
Micrograph of pre-stressed sample (pre-stressed for 48 hours) treated with 10% NaOH in relaxed condition, 40℃ for 96 hours.

The surface of the virgin polyester fiber usually contains numerous flaws or cracks, which are absent in the scanning electron micrographs (Figures 1 and 2), but can be seen using very high magnification in the form of fine surface topography.30 In PET, the molecular force in the transverse direction is much weaker than the molecular force in the longitudinal direction31 and, in thermotropic polyesters, the circumferential strength is only 20% of the longitudinal strength and the modulus is less than 10% of the longitudinal value.32 When stress is applied to the fiber, the stress concentration at the tip of each crack increases the magnitude of the crack. The line of maximum stress in the whole fiber is across a plane perpendicular to the fiber axis, and locally it is along the line of the crack opening. These two directions usually coincide to give circumferential cracks when the fiber is under stress during alkaline hydrolysis.33 Further, circumferential cracks occur during aqueous alkaline treatment in the loading condition when the load exceeds the yield load due to the transformational changes of the fiber.24,34 This conformational change exerts strain on the ester bonds that break easily due to the weakest bond energy of C-O in the ester bond.35 As for the longitudinal cracks in the applied-stressed and pre-stressed samples, the load beyond yield load increases the shear stress in the inherent defects of the fiber, thus overcoming the circumferential forces causing longitudinal cracks. These longitudinal cracks remain in the fiber and facilitate the penetration of hydroxide ions, increasing the depth and length of the longitudinal cracks.36 It is worth mentioning here that although the pH of the blood (pH ≈7.4) is much lower than the pH of the NaOH, however, the similar level of applied loading and pre-loading conditions can be encountered by implants in the human body.

No surface cracks were observed when the PET-A samples were treated with 5% sulfuric acid in the relaxed condition (figure not shown) and in the stressing condition (Figure 7: PET-A/H2SO4/246 MPa applied load). Similar surface characteristics were observed when the PET-A samples were treated with 2% (figures not shown) and 5% NH4OH in the relaxed condition (PET-A/NH4OH/zero load, Figure 8), 123 MPa loading (PET-A/NH4OH/123 MPa applied load, Figure 9) and 246 MPa loading (PET-A/NH4OH/246 MPa applied load, Figure 10). The smooth appearance of the acid and ammonium hydroxide-treated samples with 246 MPa loading conditions was surprising, as both PET-A samples (PET-A/H2SO4/246 MPa applied load; PET-A/NH4OH/246 MPa applied load) lost about 70% breaking load. The results suggest that the reaction of H2SO4 and NH4OH in relaxed and stressed conditions (below and above yield loads) takes place throughout the actual substance of the fibers with a gradual chemical degradation of PET and splitting of linkages in the long-chain polyester molecules. No cracks were observed when polyester was treated with neat n-butylamine at 21℃ for 72 hours;17 however, the formation of spiral, helical, circumferential and longitudinal cracks on various amine treated polyesters has been reported.17,37 Figure 7.
Micrograph of 2000 g stressed sample treated with 5% H2SO4, 40℃/48 hours.
Figure 8.
Scanning electron micrograph of poly(ethylene terephthalate) sample treated with 5% ammonium hydroxide, at room temperature, 120 days, under the relaxed condition.
Figure 9.
Scanning electron micrograph of PET1 treated with 5% ammonium hydroxide, at room temperature, 120 days, under 1 kg load.
Figure 10.
Micrograph of 2000g stressed sample treated with 5% NH4OH, room temp./120 days.

sec.title: Proposed chemical reaction
sec.p: The ability of NaOH to degrade the properties of polyester fibers is clearly a result of chemical reaction. Under the aqueous alkaline and relaxed condition, the hydroxide anions attack the carbonyl oxygen atoms of the of the ester group to produce one hydroxyl and one carboxylate end group.21 In the relaxed condition, the highly ionized compound cannot readily diffuse into the non-polar polyester; therefore, hydrolysis is confined to the polyester surface and only the diameter of the fiber is decreased, but the tenacity remains unchanged. However, due to the crack formation under stressing conditions, and particularly above the yield stress, diffusion of OH– occurs because the size of the OH– (3.56 Å)38 is apparently much smaller than the cracks in PET. This diffusion of OH– ions inside PET causes removal of more PET layers in stressing samples than the relaxed samples, which results in more weight loss, and the reaction produces one hydroxyl and one carboxylate end group as follows: R-COO-CH2CH2-O-OH-→RCOO-+OH-
In the acid media, protonation of the in-chain oxygen atom of the ester group, followed by reaction with water, produces one hydroxyl and one carboxyl end group:21 R-COO-CH2CH2-O-H+→RCOO-+OH-

In ammonium hydroxide, protonation occurs as the ammonium ion (NH4 +) is mildly acidic and dissociates into H+ and NH3. Since the concentration of NH4OH is relatively low, more NH4 + is produced in the bath than the hydroxide ions, and hydrolysis occurs similar to acid hydrolysis:39 NH4 +→H++NH3

sec.title: Calculation of poly(ethylene terephthalate) implant lifetime
sec.p: Previously we have reported that the weight loss (%) of medical-grade PET roughly fits the ICI formula27 [given in Equation (1)]. We have also reported an empirical equation relating loss in breaking load with treatment time and applied load for a specific NaOH concentration and treatment temperature.24 The generic empirical equation is given in Equation (2). Equations (3) and (4) were computed by Statistical Package for Social Science (SPSS) ‘Enter Method’ for PET-A and PET-B, respectively, at 40℃ and 10% NaOH concentration using breaking load (cN) data. The breaking load data for PET-A is given in Table 1 and details data for PET-B are given elsewhere:24 (1)Weightloss(%)=0.47t(x2+6x)1.082100-Td where t is the time in hours, x is the concentration of NaOH (%), T is the temperature in ℃ and d is the decitex of the fiber. (2)Y=β0+β1T+β2L2 where Y is the predicted breaking load (cN), T is the treatment time (days) and L is the applied load (g). (3)Y=47.1-3.44T-2.26*10-6L2(R2=0.85,S=2.88,95 %confidencelim=±6.27) (4)Y=56.4-4.79T-4.36*10-6L2(R2=0.90,S=3.56,95 %confidencelim=±7.77)

In Equations (3) and (4), R2 is the coefficient of determination, S is the standard deviation about regression, and 95% confidence limits for the predicted breaking load Y are given by ±t0.025 S, where t0.025 is obtained from probability points of the t distribution table using n − 2(=12) degrees of freedom.

Using Equation (3) for PET-A, the lifetime for 50% loss in breaking load for the ‘zero applied loading’ condition would be only ≈7 days in 10% NaOH at 40℃. Since the dependence of NaOH concentration with the weight loss (%) is (x2 + 6x) according to Equation (1), and assuming the rate of weight loss is proportional to breaking load loss, we can calculate the lifetime using the lower concentration of alkali that is likely to be encountered by PET implants. Hence, for 0.01% or 0.0025 M NaOH (pH < 11), the lifetime would be about 50 years in zero loading condition. Similarly for the PET-B sample, using Equation (4) and taking the dependence of NaOH (x2 + 6x), the lifetime would be about 45 years in 0.0025 M NaOH at 40℃. Since the pH of blood is only 7.4, physiological fluids alone cannot be responsible for the premature rupture of PET implants, as reported in the numerous medical literatures. However, where a premature rupture has occurred, perhaps the main contributing factor was the site-specific physiological loads that exceed the polymer yield load. Another reason for premature rupture of PET implants was the use of apparel-grade PET materials,40 as it was found that the retrieved PET implants in Hospital Saint-Joseph, Marseille, France, were manufactured from semi-dull, round cross-section, textured multifilament, Type 56T Dacron. This specific polyester was apparel grade and not meant to be used for implants. The textured and semi-dull polyesters degrade faster than the clear (bright) and flat filament polyester yarns.17

We believe that the present work is the first to compute the lifetime of PET implants. However, in this work, the empirical equations were computed for applied loading and alkaline (NaOH) conditions only, as PET implants encounter alkaline conditions in the human body due to the slightly alkaline nature of blood and physiological stress. Further, only breaking load was used for computing the empirical equations. Other mechanical properties, such as elongation, constant stress (creep), constant strain (stress relaxation) and work of rupture, can also be used to calculate the lifetime. Elongation may be a more sensitive property to monitor than breaking strength, because elongation is associated with low molecular weight chains that degrade faster than high molecular weight chains. Some PET implants experience constant stress in the human body, and for these implants lifetime prediction using creep data would be more relevant. For implants that are in a fixed position and are not allowed to move, constant strain data should be used to compute lifetime; for patients with hypertension, work of rupture may be the most appropriate. Other relevant polymer properties, such as hardness, molecular weight and carboxyl group formation, may be useful parameters for lifetime calculation, depending on the implant location in the body.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The present study concludes that it is possible to detect in vivo formation of cracks in PET implants before their implantation into the human body using an aqueous alkaline hydrolysis treatment. Both circumferential and longitudinal cracks can be predicted by treating PET in aqueous NaOH with an applied load or pre-load above the yield load. Sulfuric acid and ammonium hydroxide cannot be used to predict the surface of PET. The smooth surface of sulfuric acid and ammonium hydroxide-treated samples under stressing condition was surprising, and further studies are needed to explain the mechanism for such behavior. Physiological liquids alone cannot be responsible for the premature rupture of PET implants, as reported in numerous medical literatures. Between pH 10 and 11, PET implants should last at least 50 years in the human body without any stressing conditions. However, when premature ruptures are reported for ‘medical-grade PET’, the main reason is the synergistic effects of physiological fluids and stressing conditions in the human body.

Finally, looking at the scanning electron micrographs of degraded samples, it appears that the morphology of PET might be row-nucleated rather than spherulitic; however, to confirm this structure, further research is necessary. In order to explain the differences in crack formation and crack dimensions, detailed study about the history of the fine structure of PET fiber is required.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
